questions.question: Which factor is considered more dangerous in causing electrocution?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) AC current Explanation: Ac current is more dangerous because it causes continuous muscle contractions, making it harder to release the source of shock. It can also disrupt the heart rhythm, leading to fatal arrhythmias. Electrocution(Electrical injuries) Refers to injury or death caused by electric shock. It occurs when an electric current passes through the body, disrupting normal bodily functions, particularly the heart, muscles, and nerves. Electricity exerts two major effects on the body: Cellular depolarisation of nerves and muscles. Heat production Factors influencing electrocution: Current Type: AC (alternating current) is more dangerous than DC (direct current) at similar voltage levels because AC causes continuous muscle contractions and is more likely to induce ventricular fibrillation. Voltage Level: Electrocution is rare at <100V and most deaths occur at >200V.Amperage is more important as it indicates the actual intensity of electricity, which passes through the body. Resistance of the Body: The human body’s resistance varies by tissue type (blood, muscle, fat, and skin). Wet or broken skin decreases resistance, increasing the likelihood of severe injuries whereas dry skin offers higher resistance. Duration of Contact: Longer exposure leads to more severe injuries. Short contact may cause local burns, while prolonged contact can result in heart and respiratory failure. Pathway of Current: Death is more likely to occur if the brain stem or heart is in the direct path of the current. Effects due to passage of electricity: Low Tension Injuries (<1000V): Typically cause superficial burns at the points of entry and exit. Most common sites of low-voltage contact entry injury are hands(fingers) and that of exit injury is foot or opposite hand. Muscle contractions, tetany, and possible ventricular fibrillation may occur. Victims may suffer from arrhythmias or cardiac arrest if the current crosses the heart. High Tension Injuries (>1000V): Injuries can be caused by three sources- flash, flame or the current itself. High voltage causes deeper burns, organ damage, and massive tissue destruction. It may lead to immediate cardiac or respiratory arrest. The current can cause thermal injuries, with electricity creating heat as it passes through the body. Crocodile skin lesions : Third degree burns or red brown punch out spark lesions. Characteristics of Injuries: Entry Wounds: Typically small and well-defined, resembling a burn. In low tension injuries, the area might be red and blistered; in high tension injuries, there may be charring or significant tissue damage. questions.question: Which type of fracture is most commonly associated with seat belt injuries in motor vehicle accidents?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chance fracture of the lumbar spine Explanation : The Chance fracture/Seat belt fracture, a horizontal fracture through the vertebral body, pedicles and spinous process of the lumbar spine, is commonly associated with seat belt injuries. Chance fracture: Horizontal or transverse fracture through the vertebral body, pedicles, and spinous process, commonly affecting the lumbar spine. Mechanism of Injury: Results from a flexion-distraction force (bending and pulling apart) on the spine, typically during sudden deceleration, such as in motor vehicle accidents with improper or no shoulder restraint. Flexion-distraction spinal injury with no rotation of the fracture fragments or lateral displacement. Often associated with seat belt injuries when only the lap belt is used, leading to significant force across the lumbar spine. Most commonly occurs in the thoracolumbar region (T10-L2). Clinical Presentation: Patients may report lower back pain and possibly abdominal pain due to associated organ injuries. Diagnosis : Diagnosed through X-ray or CT scan, showing a horizontal fracture line through the posterior elements of the spine. Treatment : immobilization and surgical stabilization.Usually reduced on Risser table by applying hyper extension to the injured thoracolumbar area. Smith fracture (Option A): Distal radius fracture with palmar (volar) displacement, typically from a fall on a flexed wrist. Barton fracture (Option C): Intra-articular distal radius fracture with dislocation of the carpal bones, usually from a fall on an outstretched hand. Colles fracture (Option D): Distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement, commonly resulting from a fall on an extended wrist.

questions.question: Which among the following are usually associated with collisions over the dashboard during an RTA? 1) Posterior cruciate ligament injury 2) Posterior dislocation of hip 3) Patella fracture
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 1, 2, 3 Explanation: All of the following - posterior cruciate ligament injury , posterior dislocation of hip and fracture-patella are usually seen in dashboard injuries. Dashboard injury: Affected Front seat passenger (hip and knees flexed position) 3 Ps Patella fracture Posterior cruciate ligament injury Posterior hip dislocation Other injuries Fracture - pelvis/femur Most common nerve injured: Sciatic nerve Reference: Knight’s Forensic pathology 4th Edition, Pages 226,279. Gautam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Pages 284,285.

questions.question: What is the most likely structure to be affected in this illustration shown?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Mesentery Explanation: Illustration shown is seat belt injury - Mesentery is most commonly affected due to seatbelt injuries. Seat belts: Restraints the body against severe deceleration and hence preventing impact from windscreen, steering wheel and other obstruction. Though it slows down deceleration, it can jam at a certain point leading to injuries. Follows Inertia-reel mechanism. Primarily of two types: Shoulder diagonal (most commonly used in vehicles) Lap strap (aircrafts) Seat Belt injuries: Patterned contusion (known as Seat belt sign ) Drivers: starts from the right shoulder Passengers: starts from the left shoulder Intra-abdominal (deceleration- compression) Mesentery - most commonly affected (Option B) Small intestine: DJ flexure (primary),Ileocaecal junction (secondary) Liver, Spleen Vertebral injuries (distraction- compression) Distraction(separation of joint): seen on posterior side Compression: seen on anterior side Chance fracture: fracture involving all 3 columns of spine Seat belt syndrome Seat belt sign + intra-abdominal injuries + vertebral injuries

questions.question: Person sustained a blow to the front of the chest by the steering wheel in an RTA. Which site of the aorta is most likely to be affected?

options.A: Ascending aorta - 1.5cms proximal to ligamentum arteriosum
options.B: Ascending aorta - 1.5cms distal to ligamentum arteriosum
options.C: Descending aorta - 1.5cms proximal to ligamentum arteriosum
options.D: Descending aorta - 1.5cms distal to ligamentum arteriosum

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Descending aorta - 1.5cms distal to ligamentum arteriosum Explanation: Junction of Aortic arch with the descending aorta distal to origin of subclavian artery i.e 1.5cms distal to ligamentum arteriosum is the most likely site of tear in steering wheel injuries as the lower thoracic aorta at that point is bound to the anterior longitudinal ligament on the front of dorsal spine. Steering wheel injury: Sites affected Sternum/Ribs (Flail chest) Chest (patterned bruises seen) Elbow/forearm (pressure transmission effect) Aorta Intimal tears in aorta (either partial or complete). Site: 1.5cms distal to ligamentum arteriosum (junction of aortic arch with descending aorta) (Option D) Multiple parallel intimal tears near the main transection is known as Ladder rung tears. Osseous punch: compression of aorta between sternum and thoracic vertebra. Other organs involved Heart: Hemopericardium -> Cardiac tamponade Lungs: Pincer contusions seen Liver > Spleen Reference: Knight’s Forensic Pathology, 4th Edition, Pages 216-225.

questions.question: What is the mechanism of injury and common level affected in fracture-dislocation seen with whiplash injury
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Flexion-hyperextension; C5-C6 Explanation: Whiplash injury is caused due to violent acceleration-deceleration force leading to sudden flexion-hyperextension of head and can be associated with Fracture-dislocation of C5-C6 vertebra. Whiplash injury: (soft tissue injury) Mechanism Acceleration: hyperextension followed by hyperflexion Deceleration: hyperflexion followed by hyperextension Associated injuries Atlanto-axial dislocation > C5-C6 fracture-dislocation Anterior longitudinal ligament and cervical ligaments are torn Passenger Most commonly front seat passenger is affected Prevention Use of head restraints (head rest) prevents hyperextension of neck Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 215.

questions.question: Windshield impact to front seat passenger may impact which among the following injuries
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) All of the above Explanation: Windshield impact to either driver/front seat passenger can cause sparrow foot marks , Dicing injury , avulsion of forehead skin , basilar skull fractures. Windshield injury: Sparrow foot marks Multiple, small, punctate facial lacerations due to shattered glass pieces. Mechanism: Driver/passenger ramming onto the glass . Site: Predominantly over the face More specific for windshield injuries. Dicing injury More common than sparrow foot marks Multiple superficial cuts over the skin. Mechanism: Glass pieces falling towards the person . Site: All over the face and body Can also occur in rear seat passengers Other injuries Avulsion of forehead skin Basilar skull fractures Fracture-dislocation Reference: Gautam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Pages 284, 285.

questions.question: Which of the following is a frequent type of injury seen in tertiary impact injuries?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Contrecoup injury Explanation: Contrecoup injury occurs when the brain strikes the opposite side of the skull from where the impact occurred, often seen in tertiary impact injuries. Secondary injuries/Tertiary impact injuries Results from body parts, striking the ground, following primary and secondary impact and are more lethal. When the pedestrian is thrown to the ground, he/she sustains abrasions, bruises or lacerations over the bony prominences. Contrecoup injury: Brain damage is frequent without any associated skull fracture due to moving head of the victim, being suddenly stopped on impact, resulting in diffuse damage to the axons. Fracture of the skull and ribs due to direct contact and fracture of spine due to hyper flexion or extension. Sometimes, pedestrians are run over if knocked down by the vehicle. This will tend to occur if the pedestrian centre of gravity is lower than the impact site. Tyre tread marks on one surface of the body with graze like abrasions on the opposite side. Compression of the chest resulting in flail chest. Flaying injury: Avulsion injury when the wheel moves over a fleshy part causing degloving of skin and subcutaneous tissue by tearing it away from underlying tissue . Burning and singing of skin and hair, resulting from discharge of hot exhaust. Tailgating injury (Option B): Unique injury wherein the motorcyclist drives under the rear of the truck, causing head injuries and decapitation. Terrible triad injury (Option C): This refers to a specific set of injuries to the elbow (dislocation, radial head fracture, coronoid fracture), not related to tertiary impact. Sparrow foot marks (Option D): Peculiar facial lacerations due to contact with the shattered windscreen seen in transportation injuries.

questions.question: Which of the following is a classic pattern of injury seen in pedestrian children involved in road traffic accidents?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Waddell's Triad Explanation: Waddell's Triad is a classic pattern of injury seen in pediatric pedestrians struck by vehicles. Femoral fracture Intra-thoracic or abdominal injury Contralateral head injury. Pedestrian Injuries Most common type of transportation injuries which are blunt for injuries, the Tucker from travel on the ground, in the air and on water. Three pattern of pedestrian injuries seen: primary impact injuries Secondary impact injuries Secondary injuries / Tertiary impact injuries Primary Impact Injuries: Injuries Occur when the victim is struck by the vehicle, often following recognizable patterns. Common injuries include abrasions, lacerations, fractures of legs, thighs, or buttocks, and fractures of the fibula and tibia. When an adult is hit by a car, the impact is often at knee level, and injuries vary depending on the victim’s position and vehicle orientation. Common cause of death is due to head injury and fracture dislocation of cervical spine, mainly at the atlanto-occipital joint. Factors influencing injury behavior include Position of the victim's feet (whether they were firmly placed or raised at impact). Speed of the vehicle (low speed results in being thrown onto the bonnet; at higher speeds, the victim is projected or scooped up). Road surface type (smooth, rough, gravel). Point of impact relative to the center of gravity. When the pedestrian is knocked down from behind with both feet fixed to the ground, there will be fracture of the bones of the lower limbs. Waddell's Triad A classic pattern in pedestrian children struck by vehicles. Fractured femoral shaft. Intrathoracic or intra-abdominal injuries. Contralateral head injury. Injury Behavior Based on Position and Vehicle Impact On Being struck from behind with feet not firmly on the ground: The victim’s feet are thrown backwards. Possible head injuries from striking against the windscreen. Victims can be scooped up or fall to one side, sustaining further head injuries from striking the ground. Struck from the front: Injuries to chest, abdomen, with potential fractures of ribs or vertebrae. Pelvic or sacroiliac fractures, as well as fractures of the tibia or fibula from bumper impact. Bumper impact injuries: Soft tissue damage and fractures (typically wedge-shaped). Fractures may suggest the point of impact and movement direction of the vehicle. The location and measurement of the bumper fracture on the victim provide details about the vehicle's height and speed. Wedge type bumper fracture of the tibia seen. Marks may suggest if the victim was walking or lying on the road when struck. When the pedestrian walks into the side of a moving vehicle Glancing abrasions Crushing lacerations on the side or front of the face, chest and arms. Fracture of ribs with or without laceration. Sustain secondary injuries Fracture of the skull occurs due to direct impact of the vehicle on the head. Secondary impact injuries: Often seen in cases of scooped up victims being thrown over the bonnet. The person sustains injuries by hitting his head against the windscreen, its rim or side pillars. questions.question: What is a unique type of injury often associated with motorcyclists?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Tailgating Explanation: Tailgating/Under-running is a unique injury wherein the motorcyclist drives under the rear of the truck, causing head injuries and decapitation. Motorcycle Injuries An accident that might result in minor injuries with an automobile,can result in death with a motorcycle. Motorcyclists experience death rate 35 times greater than the occupants of a car. Most common causes of motorcycle accidents are alcohol, drugs and environmental factors like potholes, bumps, reckless driving. Most common cause of motorcycle fatality is running off the road. Most injuries are due to ejection from the vehicle into the roads, due to high speed and instability of the vehicle. Primary injuries: Open fracture of tibia and fibula. Secondary injuries: Fractures of skull, ribs and cervical spine. Hinge fracture / Motorcyclist fracture: Transverse fracture of the base of the skull is common Temporo-parietal fractures are also common with ring fractures around foramen magnum. Passengers falling off the backs of the motorcycle will have lacerations of the back of the head, fractures of posterior cranial fossa. Blood samples should be analysed for the presence and amount of alcohol and drugs, if consumed since the question of contributory negligence may subsequently arise. Bone pearls (Option A): Small, rounded calcifications seen in electrocution. Lichtenberg flowers (Option B): Skin patterns seen after a lightning strike. Whiplash (Option C): Neck injury caused by rapid back-and-forth movement, commonly seen in car accidents but not specific to motorcyclists. Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd Edition, Page 286, 287.

questions.question: Which of the following is a pathognomonic feature of a lightning strike injury?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Lichtenberg figures (Lichtenberg flowers) Explanation: Lichtenberg flowers: These are characteristic fern-like patterns that appear on the skin following a lightning strike. Lightning stroke Lightning bolt(DC>1000 million V) is produced when the charged undersurface of a thundercloud sends its electrical charge to the ground. Death is caused by high voltage current due to cardiopulmonary arrest or electrothermal injuries. Lichtenberg flowers/Arborescent markings: Pathognomic feature of lightning strike. Superficial, several inches long, thin, irregular, tortuous, dendritic red marks on the skin having resemblance to the branches of a tree. This Fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin is usually found over the shoulders or flanks. Appears within 1hr and disappears in 24-48 hrs if person survives. Other features of lightning strike: Development of edema of skin at the point of entry wound. Linear burns and surface burns Fusing and magnetisation of metallic articles. Contusions, lacerations, rupture of tympanic membrane. Singed hair and patterned skin burns marks underneath metal articles of jewellery. Joule burns (Option B): These are burns caused by the conversion of electrical energy into heat within the body and are not specific to lightning strikes. They can occur in any electrical injury. Crocodile skin lesions (Option C): These are indicative of other types of electrical injuries, characterized by a specific pattern of skin damage but are not unique to lightning strikes. Sparrow foot marks (Option D): Peculiar facial lacerations due to contact with the shattered windscreen seen in transportation injuries.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes 'Hide and die' syndrome? due to mental confusion from hypothermia

options.A: It occurs when hypothermic victims discard their clothing due to overheating sensations
options.B: It is characterized by the victim pulling household items over themselves or hiding in unusual places,
options.C: It refers to a skin condition caused by prolonged exposure to cold, resulting in ulcerative lesions
options.D: It is the result of an intentional attempt by victims to escape from a dangerous situation

questions.explanation: hiding in unusual places, due to mental confusion from hypothermia Correct Answer: B) It is characterized by the victim pulling household items over themselves or hiding in unusual places, due to mental confusion from hypothermia Explanation: In the ‘hide and die' syndrome, the body of a hypothermia victim is found in unusual locations resembling an attempt to "hide" or create a protective environment due to mental confusion and a possible hibernation reflex (confused with signs of homicide or robbery) Hypothermia: Definition Core temperature below 36°C (96.8°F) Signs Disorientation Dulling of consciousness Loss of reflex Fall in respiration, heart rate, and blood pressure Red patches and pallor of the skin Edema of the face Stiffness of neck muscles Autopsy findings Patches of pink to brownish-pink discoloration Postmortem staining: Pink/bright red Cyanosis or pallor in extremities ("white deaths") Edema of feet and blistering of skin Stomach: Wischnewsky spots- brownish black colored gastric mucosal ulcers Viscera-congested, hemorrhagic Phenomena seen in hypothermia victims Paradoxical undressing - found undressed due to disorientation which increases heat loss (mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide) (Option A ruled out) ‘Hide and die' syndrome- found in unusual locations resembling an attempt to "hide" or create a protective environment due to mental confusion and a possible hibernation reflex (confused with signs of homicide or robbery) (Option B) Chilblain (Erythema Pernio)- red, itching skin lesions typically found on extremities due to cold exposure, often accompanied by edema and blistering. Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, pages 263-264

questions.question: A forensic pathologist is tasked with determining whether the burns on a severely charred body occurred before or after death. During the examination, the pathologist observes a combination of findings, some of which are more suggestive of antemortem burns. Which of the following combinations of findings is least indicative of antemortem burns?

options.A: Elevated carbon monoxide levels and soot in the trachea
options.B: Pugilistic attitude and blisters filled with clear fluid
options.C: Presence of an inflammatory reaction at the burn edges and cherry-red discoloration of the skin
options.D: Blisters filled with protein-rich fluid and soot in the upper respiratory tract

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pugilistic attitude and blisters filled with clear fluid Explanation While common in burn victims , pugilistic posture is a non-specific finding and can occur whether the individual was alive or dead at the time of the burn. Non specific findings in burns cases Phenomenon Description Cause Key Features Medico-Legal Significance Puppet Organs Internal organs become shriveled, firm, and hardened by heat. Prolonged exposure to high temperatures. Organs resemble firm, "cooked" structures. Shows prolonged heat exposure. Heat Hematoma Large artifact resembling extradural hematoma, containing 100–120 ml of blood. Blood from longitudinal venous sinuses or diploic veins. 1.5 cm thick; the heat forces blood from calvarium through veins onto dura. Resembles extradural hematoma. Heat Ruptures Skin splits resembling incised or lacerated wounds due to heat contraction of tissue. Contraction of heated, coagulated tissue. Fissures contain nerves, vessels, connective tissue; no clotted blood, irregular margins, no bruising. Differentiates heat damage from violent injury. Pugilistic Attitude Flexed posture of arms and legs resembling a boxing stance. Coagulation of muscle proteins and dehydration. Flexor muscles contract more than extensors; seen in cremations. No significance whether alive or dead pre-burn. Heat Fractures Fractures caused by heat, with long bones showing curved fractures. Muscle shrinkage pulls on tendons and bones during exposure to high heat. Heat fractures do not involve skull sutures; neurocranium remains as fragments up to 10 cm; hyoid can become fragile. Identifies extreme heat exposure and helps distinguish heat fractures from trauma. Heat Hematoma Heat Ruptures Pugilistic Attitude Heat Fractures

questions.question: A police surgeon is tasked with determining whether the burns on a deceased individual occurred before or after death. The body was discovered in a residential fire, and toxicology revealed elevated carbon monoxide levels. Which among the following findings is more relatable to the elevated carbon monoxide levels?

options.A: Absence of soot in the upper respiratory tract
options.B: Blisters filled with clear fluid and air
options.C: Presence of an inflammatory reaction at the burn edges

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Presence of an inflammatory reaction at the burn edges Explanation: Presence of an inflammatory reaction at the burn edges is more relatable to elevated carbon monoxide levels because both indicate that the individual was alive during the fire. Inflammatory reactions at burn edges occur only if the body is still capable of mounting a physiological response to the burn, which requires the individual to be alive. S.No Feature Antemortem burns Postmortem burns 1 Line of redness Present Absent 2 Vesicles (Option B and D ruled out) Contain serous fluid, rich in albumin, chloride, and some polymorphs Contain air; if fluid is present, it contains little albumin and no chloride 3 Base of vesicles Red and inflamed Dull, dry, hard and yellow 4 Soot in upper respiratory tract (Option A ruled out) May be present Absent 5 Inflammation and repair Present along with pus and slough Absent 6 Healing Granulation tissue seen in old cases Absent 7 Carboxyhemoglobin Present Absent 8 Enzyme reaction Increase in enzymes in the periphery of burns No such increase Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, page 273

questions.question: A 25-year-old male sustains second-degree burns covering 40% of his total body surface area (TBSA) in an industrial accident. According to the Parkland formula, how much fluid should be administered within the first 24 hours?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 12,000 mL Explanation: To calculate fluid requirement in burn patients, the Parkland formula is used: Parkland Formula = 4 mL × body weight (kg) × %TBSA burned Given: Age = 25 years TBSA = 40% Assuming average weight = 70 kg (standard unless otherwise specified) TBSA (%) × Weight (kg) × 4 = Volume (ml) to be administered Step-by-step calculation: = 4 × 70 × 40 = 11,200 mL of fluid required in the first 24 hours ~ 12,000 mL Fluid administration schedule: 50% of total in the first 8 hours Remaining 50% over the next 16 hours Medico-legal Aspect 1st Degree burns Simple 2nd Degree burns Grievous 3rd Degree burns Grievous Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, page 269, 270

questions.question: A 7 year old child is admitted in ER with burns to the entire posterior trunk and the left lower limb. Using the Lund and Browder chart, calculate the percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 35% Explanation Lund and Browder Chart adjusts the percentage of body surface area burned according to the patient’s age, accounting for developmental changes in body proportions. For a 7-year-old: Posterior trunk: 18% of TBSA. Left lower limb: (14 + 6 x 0.5)% of TBSA = 17% of TBSA. Total affected TBSA = 18% + 17% = 35%. The use of the Lund and Browder chart is vital in forensic cases to accurately assess injury severity in cases of burns in children. The estimation of Total Body Surface Area (TBSA) using Wallace's Rule of Nines is not precise for children due to their proportionately larger head surface area. Body Surface Area Assessment in Children (Lund and Browder Chart) Baseline Percentages (Under 1 Year) Head: 18% of Total Body Surface Area (TBSA) Each Leg: 14% of TBSA Trunk and Arms: Same as adult percentages Age Adjustment Formula For each year over age 1: Add 0.5% to each leg Subtract 1.0% from head Continue adjustments until adult values are reached. Example Calculation For a 3-year-old child: Start with baseline values Adjust for 2 years (age 1 to 3): Legs: 14% + (2 × 0.5%) = 15% each Head: 18% - (2 × 1.0%) = 16% Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, page 269

questions.question: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with burns covering his anterior trunk and anterior right upper limb. Using the Wallace Rule of Nines, what percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) is affected, and how does this correlate with forensic medicine in terms of assessing the severity and cause of injury?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 22.5% Explanation According to the Wallace Rule of Nines, the anterior trunk accounts for 18% of TBSA, and the anterior right upper limb contributes an additional 4.5%, making a total of 22.5% in this scenario. This rule is essential in estimating burn severity and planning fluid resuscitation. questions.question: Destruction of superficial skin is classified under which category in Wilson’s classification of burns?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Dermo-epidermal Explanation: Destruction of superficial skin or whole skin including the dermis is categorized under dermo-epidermal burns in Wilson’s classification of burns Wilson’s classification of burns: Category Degree of damage Epidermal (Option A ruled out) Erythema Vesication with blister formation Dermo-epidermal (Option C) Destruction of superficial skin Destruction of whole skin including dermis Deep (Option D ruled out) Destruction of deep fascia, muscles Complete charing involving vessels, nerves, bones Another classification of burns - Dupuytren’s Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, page 268

questions.question: Match the following types of burns with its characteristics Type of heat Characteristic 1. Dry heat burn a. Vesicles over the burned area 2. Moist heat burn b. No vesicles present 3. Chemical burn c. Vesicles at the circumference of the burnt area
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b Explanation: Feature Dry Heat Burn Moist Heat Burn Chemical Burn Cause Flame, heated body, or X-rays Solid steam or liquid > 60ºC Corrosives Site At or above the site of contact At and below the site of contact At or below the site of contact Splashing Absent Present Present Skin Dry, wrinkled, and may be charred Sodden, bleached Corroded and devitalized Vesicles At the circumference of the burnt area Over the burnt area Usually not present Redline Present Present Absent Color Black Bleached Distinctive coloration Charring Present Absent Absent Singeing Present Absent Absent Ulceration Absent Absent Present Scar Thick, contracted Thin, less contracted Thick, contracted Clothes Burnt Wet, not burnt It may be burnt, with characteristic stains Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, page 274

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding heat stroke is wrong?

options.B: Core body temperature of more than 40.5°C

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Sweating is present Explanation: Sweating is absent in heat stroke but present in exertional heat stroke Condition Cause Clinical Features Postmortem Findings Heat Cramps (Miner’s/Stoker’s/Fireman’s Cramps) Fluid and electrolyte depletion (dilutional hyponatremia), following vigorous activity and profuse sweating. Sudden severe muscle cramps (arms, legs, abdomen) Tender, hard, lumpy muscles Flushed face, dilated pupils, dizziness, vomiting Moist, cool skin, body temperature normal/slightly elevated Non-specific Heat Exhaustion Prolonged strenuous activity with inadequate water/salt intake in a hot environment. questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding immersion syndrome and frostbite is false?

options.B: Pressure is applied in frostbite treatment
options.C: Dampness is required for immersion syndrome
options.D: Tetanus prophylaxis is given in frostbite cases with deep infection

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pressure is applied for frostbite Explanation: Pressure or friction is avoided in frostbite Condition Cause Symptoms Treatment Immersion Syndrome (Trench/Immersion Foot/Hand) Prolonged exposure to severe cold (<10ºC) and dampness (common in warfare, trenches, or sea immersion) (Option C ruled out) Affects extremities (feet, hands) (Option A ruled out) Cold, numbness, burning, cyanosis Air drying, protecting extremities from trauma and infection, gradual rewarming by air exposure at room temperature (avoid heat, massaging, or moistening the skin) Frostbite Exposure to extreme cold (-2.5ºC), causing tissue freezing and blood supply obstruction Blue-black disco No loration of fingers, toes, nose, ears, face. Mild cases: numbness, prickling. Severe cases: paresthesia, stiffness, necrosis, gangrene, edema, blisters. Rewarming: For superficial frostbite (frostnip): Firm steady pressure is applied with a warm hand (without rubbing), by placing fingers in the armpits and for the feet, by covering with dry socks For deep frostbite: Frozen extremity is immersed for several minutes in a moving water bath, heated to 40–42°C, until the distal tip of the part being thawed, flushes Pressure or friction is avoided (Option B) Anti-infective measures: Tetanus prophylaxis and antibiotics for deep infection (Option D ruled out)
